qas.question: What is the gourmet title given to pigeons ?
From what variety of pigeon does the squab decen?
Are squabs treated differently from other piegons by humans aside from consumption?

answers.text: When they hatch, the squabs are fed by both parents on "pigeon's milk", a thick secretion high in protein produced by the crop

qas.question: How often are pigeons able to breed for the consumption process ?

answers.text: a prolific pair should produce two squabs every four weeks during a breeding season lasting several months

qas.question: What is the gourmet title that was taken away from pigeons?
What variety of pigeon does the squab avoid?

plausible_answers.text: By this time, the adult pigeons will have laid and be incubating another pair of eggs

qas.question: Why does the breeding season only last a few days?
How many squabs do most pigeon pairs make in their lifetime?

context: <a0_0>A <b4_0>squab<b4_0/><a0_0/> is the name given to the young of domestic pigeons that are destined for the table. Like other domesticated pigeons, birds used for this purpose are descended from the <a1_0><b5_0>rock pigeon (Columba livia)<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Special utility breeds with desirable characteristics are used. Two eggs are laid and incubated for about 17 days. <a2_0>When they hatch, the squabs are fed by both parents on "pigeon's milk", a thick secretion high in protein produced by the crop<a2_0/>. Squabs grow rapidly, but are slow to fledge and are ready to leave the nest at 26 to 30 days weighing about 500 g (18 oz). <b6_0>By this time, the adult pigeons will have laid and be incubating another pair of eggs<b6_0/> and <a3_0>a prolific pair should produce <b7_0>two<b7_0/> squabs every four weeks during a breeding season lasting several months<a3_0/>.
